description.narrative:
The time is right to pressure both DFIs and commercial banks, especially on the interconnectedness between the two. Using the research and scoring methodology of the Fair Finance Guide International (FFGI) to assess and score Development Finance Institutions (DFIs) and making these scores visible and public, is likely to be a good strategy to illuminate the workings of the DFIs and lend additional strength to campaigns of civil society actors working on either commercial finance or development finance. This project is intended to present possibilities for applying the FFGI methodology to DFI#s, as well as providing capacity building for researchers inthe upcoming South African FFGI coalition. Project preparation
An introduction session with Profundo, CER and partners, will be held to start the work on DFIs and the capacity building of the CER researchers. This session is intended to share the lessons learnedby the coalition currently working on the AfDB and to gather input for the learning questions.
2. Capacity building of CER researchers As a start, Profundo will give the standard introduction training. oThe aim of this training and the support provided is that the CER researchers will conduct a policy assessment of the DBSA and IDB.
3. FFGI Methodology policy assessment pilot. A policy analysis of the investment frameworks of five DFIs will be done, on the mandatory cross-cutting themes and two more appropriate sectors(depending on the portfolio). Relevant financial categories will differ from commercial financial institutions, as DFIs do not holdshares, bonds or conduct asset management, and therefore the FFGI Methodology frameworks but it is not fully clear yet how these policies are applied when corporations and projects are financed through financial intermediaries. The trial assessment will provide more insight on how policies on financial intermediaries are formulated and presented.
The second part of the pilot consists of CER hosting a workshop and finalizing the launch of the report. Due to the corona situation, instead tehre have been several webinars some with global participation. The extension is to implement one case study.

participating-org.narrative: Centre for Environmental Rigths NPC (A non-profit company)

he Centre for Environmental Rights is a non-profit organisation and law clinic based in Cape Town, South Africa. We are activist lawyers who help communities and civil society organisations in South Africa realise our Constitutional right to a healthy environmentby advocating and litigating for environmental justice.
HISTORY The Centre was established in October 2009 by eight non-profit civil society organisations in South Africa’s environmental and environmental justice sector to provide legal and related support to environmental public interest organisations, community organisations and communities. We opened our doors in April 2010.
VISION We seek a just, equitable, compassionate society which is resilient, celebrates diversity, and respects the inter-dependence between people and the environment.
MISSION The Centre for Environmental Rights defends the right of communities and civil society organisations to an environment not harmful to health or wellbeing for present and future generations. By advocating and litigating for environmental justice, we seek to advance our vision of a just, equitable, compassionate society which is resilient, celebrates diversity, and respects the inter-dependence between people and the environment
VALUES In light of the irrefutable relationship between the protection of the environment and the realisation of other human rights, the Centre for Environmental Rights is committed to defending the right of communities and civil society organisations to an environment not harmful to health or wellbeing for present and futuregenerations.
In the context of South Africa’s history of profound injustice, we strive to shift dominant exclusionary structures, narratives, and practices in our engagements within theorganisation, with clients, communities, partners, funders, service providers, government, and industry, in the pursuit of environmental justice.
We work with passion, integrity, courage, and humility, striving to be innovative, collaborative, and dedicated to excellence. We are responsive to, and work to empower and build agency in each other, our clients, and our partners. We continuously reflect on our work, and our impacts.
Our work environment is an inclusive and empathetic space, in which we check our assumptions about each other, and are conscious in our language and behaviour. We commit to having honest and courageous conversations, adapting our behaviour where necessary, in order to realise diversity, inclusion, and transformation.
